title: Wisdom for Righteous Living
shortSummary: Proverbs 21 offers practical wisdom on the condition of the human heart, the sovereignty of God over rulers, and the importance of righteousness, justice, and diligence. It contrasts the outcomes of the wicked and the righteous, emphasizing God’s ultimate control and the blessings of living according to His ways.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - Traditional period of Solomon's authorship of Proverbs

keyCharacters.name: The King
keyCharacters.description: A ruler whose heart is sovereignly directed by the LORD, illustrating God's control over earthly authority.

keyCharacters.name: The Wicked
keyCharacters.description: Individuals characterized by pride, deceit, and injustice, whose actions lead to destruction.

keyCharacters.name: The Righteous
keyCharacters.description: Those who pursue justice, mercy, and wisdom, receiving God’s favor and blessing.

keyCharacters.name: The Scorner
keyCharacters.description: A mocker or scoffer whose punishment serves as a warning and teaching moment for the simple and wise.

definitions.definition: An attitude of pride or arrogance, looking down on others.
Perverse or stubbornly contrary in behavior or attitude.
One who mocks or ridicules, often rejecting wisdom and correction.
Futility or emptiness; something without lasting value or meaning.

outline.heading: God’s Sovereignty and Human Hearts
outline.description: These verses affirm God’s control over kings and human intentions, contrasting man’s self-justification with God’s judgment of the heart, and highlighting the value of diligence over haste.

outline.heading: The Consequences of Wickedness and Pride
outline.description: This section warns against dishonest gain, refusal to do justice, and pride, showing that such behavior leads to destruction, while punishment of the scorner brings wisdom.

outline.heading: Justice, Mercy, and the Righteous Life
outline.description: Emphasizes the importance of justice and mercy over sacrifice, the dangers of folly and contentiousness, and the blessings that come from pursuing righteousness and wise stewardship.

outline.heading: Wisdom in Speech and Conduct
outline.description: Highlights the power of wisdom to overcome challenges, the importance of guarding one’s speech, the folly of pride and laziness, and concludes with the reminder that ultimate safety rests in the LORD.

application: Trust in God’s sovereign control over all circumstances, including leadership and personal decisions, and seek His guidance in prayer.
Pursue justice and mercy in daily life, valuing righteous actions above ritual sacrifices or outward appearances.
Cultivate diligence and self-control, avoiding pride, haste, and laziness to experience God’s provision and blessing.
Guard your speech carefully, recognizing that wise words protect your soul and promote peace.

keyVerses.text: The king's heart is in the hand of the LORD, as the rivers of water: he turneth it whithersoever he will.
keyVerses.significance: This verse powerfully declares God’s sovereign authority over rulers and human affairs.

keyVerses.text: To do justice and judgment is more acceptable to the LORD than sacrifice.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes that God values righteous living and justice above religious ritual.

keyVerses.text: Whoso keepeth his mouth and his tongue keepeth his soul from troubles.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches the vital importance of controlling one’s speech to avoid unnecessary harm.

keyVerses.text: The horse is prepared against the day of battle: but safety is of the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: It reminds believers that human preparation is important, but ultimate deliverance comes from God alone.
